person.persName: Abu Baker Mohamad Ben Abrahim Almari Alcarschi

tei:div.ab: decreasing daily as that of Madrid will at length entirely supersede it. The soil is sandy (and the rocks entirely of coarse granite) like that of Falmouth This passage does not follow on from the previous page, though they are recto and verso of the same leaf. Perhaps WG had a loose sheet, to which the symbol + presumably relates. It does not link to any obvious passage in the notebook.

figure.label: Fountain

tei:div.ab: North of the Town in the way to the tower of Hercules or new light house is a fountain ornamented like those of Greece. The base seems Roman upon which some statues or other modern additions have been placed, now destroyed

the city & lodge at the Casa de PortuguesesPortuguese House – where the people were very civil – The bill for 3 persons & two Servants for Lodging 2 night 2 dinners & two breakfasts, was 198 reals or about 10 dollars. The Napoleon was on the staircase & the performer was subject to the inspection of passengers – Our passports were examined with an apology for the times which made it necessary. On walking out to see the Cathedral we asked the way & a person shewed it us. A second joined us & then a third who introduced us to the JuntaProvincial government in the College. They were very civil & much pleased with the head of the king on a halfpenny. They complained that more money had been sent to Corunna instead of to the central JuntaPerhaps of Galicia, but probably the Supreme Central Junta (central authority during the Napoleonic occupation).. The view from the court of the College of the
tei:div.note:
25 Sep at St YagoSantiago de Compostela rain almost all day Verses handed about at Dn Don Juan Berillas dinner
Por Pracmatica sancion
Se ha mandado publicar
De que el vasa de cagar
Se llame: Napoleon:
Y, por la misma razon
Por esta Ley, se decreta
Se publique en la Gazeta
En un capitulo à parte
Que se llame Buonaparte
Toda comun ou secreta
By Pragmatic sanction,
It has been ordered to be made known
That the crock of shit
Is called Napoleon:
And, for the same reason
By this Law, it is decreed
That it be published in the Gazette
In a separate chapter
Called Buonoparte
All common or secret
Mandase publicar pra. qe. el language sea general. Ordered to be published so that the language is widespread.
It was plain that no money was wanted in Spain for none of the English money had ever been sent from Corunna to the army.
tei:div.ab: towers of the Cathedral was striking. We visited the Plaza Mayor on the N north side of the cathedral. A very small part of the ancient building remains of the W west end of the Cathedral, more Saxon than Gothic. [drawing: building] but within at this end is a very fine screen with [drawing: arch] arches round which the heavenly choir are carved, with harps &c. The Cathedral is not more than two centuries old & besides being very large is the finest pile of building in the style of Inigo Jones I ever saw. The roof is entirely of fine white uncoloured stone with [drawing: arch] arches, sometimes not quite regular. It is very lofty so as to have the proportions of a Gothic church. The Shrine of St JagoSt James is entirely of silver, the body is buried below. There is a very fine organ. St Jago was seen in a vision driving the Moors out of Spain.

figure.note: Pen and ink plan: Santiago de Compostela
figure.label: Free Stone a building in which the metopes are windows
A tower of the cathedral hangs on in this manner

tei:div.note: Encima la sacristia de la catedral de Santiago y sobre un arco toral de la obra vieja. Para gloria de Dios acabó esta obra Miguel de Bozllar natural de S. Miguel de Areno. Año de 1245. Above the sacristy of St James's cathedral and on a central arch of the old work. For the glory of God, Miguel de Bozllar, a native of San Miguel de Areno, finished this work. The year 1245. Spanish text abridged from Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, p. 52.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: street scene
figure.label: Sep 24 VillVillage of Caral 5 leagues from Coruña

tei:div.ab: Quitting Corunna at 6 in the morning of Septr 24th in a coach drawn by 6 mules, Our passports from the junta were examined at the gate. At 20 minutes before 7 reach PalaviaPalavea, where we had dined the day before, landing at the mouth of the river of PaçajeWG seems to mean the Ría da Coruña (Estuary of A Coruña), the mouth of the Mero river.
Our mules were called Valerosa ‘Ortolana Palagrina Gagliarda Platena & Cahona or Cajona.

figure.label: Venta de OrdinesCountry inn at Ordes

tei:div.ab: and ascending among vineyards chestnuts & hedges of Baytree. Our host was named Don Juan de Barila and treated us magnificently at his Villa. Each course consisted of 18 dishes

as represented over the door of his church at Coruña in the 8th century as we were told – Almost every building in the City is in the same stile of architecture, all very massive but some highly ornamented. The humidity of the climate has taken much from the beauty of many of the edifices. Upon the whole perhaps there is no provincial town better adorned with fine buildings. The Seminary Nnorth of the great square is very magnificent & regular, an academy makes the Eeast side the splendid cathedral the Ssouth & an Hospital excellently provided with beds & assistance for the sick, has a very noble front to the E of the Square. We heard music in the Cathedral from the Archbishops tribunal, with
tei:div.note: Alhagib captain of KgKing of CordovaKing of Cordoba entered Galicia & sacked St YagoSantiago de Compostela & took the great bells to the mosque at Cordova but in 1236 D.Don Fernando retook them & made the Moors carry them back on their shoulders.
tei:div.ab: At 25m to 11 pass the 4th10.35 stone on the top of the mountain which is bleak & like a Westmoreland Moor.

Maize. At 15 p 1115.11 the streams run toward the South. Several poor Inns or VentasCountry inns in the way. A Village & at 18 to 12 the 5th stone [drawing: league stone] . The country is very poor in appearance but does not want habitations even at this elevation. At 15 p 12 the Venta di OrdinesCountry inn at Ordes on the road side where we stopped to refresh. The house is entered by a porch, next a passage appears on Rright of which is the stable the mules eating with their heads towards the kitchen which is on the L.left Above the stable is a room with 3 windows, 4 beds of straw on wooden frames, two tables, a chest & some chairs to sit upon, A deal cross & two pictures of the Virgin.
tei:div.note: The whole or nearly all the country is enclosed but the mode of tillage seems to be to cultivate each field once in 5 years in which interval it becomes full of high furze & heath & appears quite neglected. It is then pared & burned.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of A Coruña
figure.label: Citadel.
River PasajaWG seems to mean the Ría del Pasaje estuary at A Coruña.
Isthmus St Lucia

tei:div.ab: The town of Corunna is placed on a peninsula Coarse Granitewhich joins a high knoll to the main land The port is very secure. The ancient name was Adabicum. About 5 miles up the river which falls into the port Ssouth of the town is a bridge of 13 arches & near it was the town of Brigantium
The Country though rocky seems to produce figs grapes melons capsicums &c in great abundance in September.
24 often rainy in

Eggs wine & bread were to be found & they made us an excellent omelet. Many soldiers were on the road to join the Galician army at Coruña. At 25 minutes to 2 proceed. 25 p 22.25 Xcross a stream running to Rright, a Village before it. 3 to 3qui.e. WG is asking himself whether it really was nearly 3pm. larger stream & house. 7 p 3 X
[drawing: arch bridge] river runs R [drawing: map] 45 p 3 7th League. 7 to 4 a VillVillage & church +. in a Valley on R a river is seen. 15 p 4 X [drawing: arch bridge] runs R. a village & X a great [drawing: arch bridge] TambraTambre (river) to L.left 25 p 4 a grove on R full of men women & oxen, making a very picturesque appearance, probably a fair where oxen were sold for the people were leading them home in every direction.

45 p 4 VentaCountry inn 8 leagues. At 6h a few houses & place like an encampment on a hill R. X a [drawing: arch bridge] running R. A Venta. 5m to 65.55 9 league stone cultivation improves. At 6h on a hill see St Yago de CompostellaSantiago de Compostela one an eminence & ornamted by 6 spires – At 20 p 6, enter

label.rs: PUENTA DE CORZUNBridge [puente] of Corzun [from WG's account, probably at As Nogais, which the British called Nogales].

figure.label: finished 8 years ago
village

tei:div.ab: This the English shortly afterwards attempted To blow up & failed so that the french passed with all their artillery & harassed Sir Jon Moores flying army all the way to Corunna.

long ascent, pretty bottom, all along which are watered meadows. [drawing: map] The river runs with the road. ascend. 10 p 55.10 a Vill Village down a dreadful descent L left
[drawing: valley] quit that valley & turn over a top into another where the river joins the last & both run towards Asturias North.

figure.label: Along this road the English fled

tei:div.ab: Pass a kind of Barrier but no toll was taken. At 10 minutes to 7 the road to Madrid by BetancosBetanzos turns off LLeft. The country is very well cultivated. Maize in abundance. Some Pines.

At 7 past 7 in a bottom a stream running to the left. Pretty Villas & vineyards, Chest nuts Walnuts & Oaks. The cloaks of the peasants going to market very becoming. At 35 p 77.35 after a steep hill in a bottom, a river runs to L. A fine valley with a MtMountain in the centre

A high mountain bounds the vale on S.south At 5 to 8 pass the 2 league stone [drawing: league stone] . At 10 to 9 stops at the village of Carral – 10 past 9 proceed. At 20 p 9 the 3d League stone. the valley delightful with gardens & orchards. Black sheep. Chestnuts. At 25 past 9 cross a clear stream running to L. many houses. 18 p 10 cross a ravine [drawing: ravine] after a terrible ascent from the stream. The road always good

figure.label: Villa Boa

tei:div.ab: The country like Achaia, but valleys green. uncommonly fine and awful descent from the road to river. 30 p 55.30 a pretty church & sycamore L left with magnificent views each way, a house R. right descend. 40 p 5 + church L near the river at bottom. 5 to 65.55 22d league, 5 p 6 Vill X Village cross the river of the valley by a [drawing: arch bridge] . a toll bar. after this a little [drawing: arch bridge] yethe stream of which joins the great river of the valley. 25 p 6 arrive. decent PosadaInn of Los NogalesAs Nogais. A small village like a welch town very wet & dirty. The host a great sportsman. His gun made at Ribadeo cost 60 Dollars & was very neat. Sepr 30 quit Los Nogales at 15m to 87.45 X [drawing: arch bridge] over the stream of the valley 15 p 8 a Glen runs up to L up which 13 intersections of the mountains are seen. Very steep ascent. 30 p 8 23d League. Very steep. chestnuts. 36 a Village called Conco qu? DoncoDoncos. WG is not sure if the village is called Conco or Donco.. 15 p 9 a poor Village another valley R the stream of which runs all the way to Villa FrancaVillafranca del Bierzo. 10 p 10 a kind of top but still there is a higher. at 15 to 11 descend. Summer
tei:div.note: Rained in the night & till the Vill of El CastroPossibly Castelo on Sep 30, but the road lies on very high Mts Mountains

A Country house of DDon Juan de Barila Monastery opposite Corunna
This house was at least 10 miles distant but was drawn with a camera lucida fixid to a Telescope.

tei:div.ab: his Sister, a good humoured old Lady who never ceased talking during the whole Service. [Pen and ink drawing: woman] The people were astonished at our dining at five, and came before we had finished to conduct us to the Cathedral to hear singing & .. Un CaponA Capon, i.e. a eunuch. We saw the convent of the Benedictines near the cathedral a very magnificent building of the Inigo Jones doric order. It had several courts & a very fine library in which were the books forbidden by the Inquisition about 150 feet long. The stair case to it was the most solid I ever saw. There are 100 monks who have immense revenues & 100 servants. The church is large, very lofty & not handsome. The roof vaulted & there is a perfectly flat arch [drawing: arch] of 14 yards across over one part.
tei:div.note: The inner line shews by how little this must hang
tei:div.ab: two hills like stations [drawing: hills] seen
the bay rather [pencil, pen and ink drawing: ‘Entrance of Pacaje’] ‘Entrance of Pacaje’WG seems to mean the Ría da Coruña (Estuary of A Coruña), the mouth of the Mero river.

pretty, & perfectly landlocked. At 11m to 109.49 the 3d league, abt 10habout 10am the [drawing] close L.left 28 p 1010.28 a + La church on the left see & descend to BetançosBetanzos entirely surrounded with vines. met a coach & 7 mules

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Betanzos

tei:div.note: Tamarisk bushes in the bed of the river
tei:div.ab: the town is in the bottom of a valley on the Rright bank of the river. A [drawing: arch bridge] with several tamarisk bushes. At 10 p 11 arrive in the town, full of Vines & terraces. The Plaza is full of Posadas Posada della Cruz. del Sole. de la Aurora & ours of L’Estrellafull of Inns: the Cross Inn, the Sun [sol] Inn, the Dawn Inn and ours, the Star Inn, a very good house where they killed 2 chickens, scalded off the feathers & made a very good stew with potatoes, & an omelet with Tomatas for which 2 of us & 2 servants paid 2 dollars & about 6 pence; There is a building
30 p 1212.30 a stream & [drawing: arch bridge] runs L. left a toll bar, a Vill R. Village right

40 p 11 steep ascent Village ConstantinProbably Constantín, though WG has crossed out the 'n'. . 10 p 12 very long ascent curious Gothic Rock very like a ruin*. Small vill near it R. 3 Villages R & pretty Valley. still ascend. 20 to 112.40 top Glen & houses L. 10 to 1 League 20. The river in the new valley runs back 9m 9 miles to Asturias; perhaps into the Minho. 20 p 1 arrive at Santa IsabellaSanta Isabel. A very wretched VentaCountry inn with only one room a travelling hurdy gurdy man, very civil drivers of oxen. hens cat dog & pig all in the room. A great caldron on the fire boiling potatoes greens &c. for the pigs.

At 15 p 4 quit St Isabella. very fine Mountains A high cold place on getting into next valley. The hills very lofty but up to the top cultivated, the bottoms full of chestnut trees. descend, Vill L.Better climate
10 p 4 Vill. fine view & chestnuts.
20 p 4 Vill up another branch of Vale L 3 miles dist & large 35 p 4 21 leagues & pretty Vill L. 40 p 4 X cross a magnificent bridge over a bottom called

figure.label: Gate of StSantiagoSt James. Yago Corunna.

tei:div.ab: The Church of St Yago at Corunna. The Saint is represented driving the Moors before Him. The Church contains several altars & a large organ but is not handsome. Thermometer 76 Sep 22d.
for the view. A village cross it.
40 p 66.40 15th League river beautiful.
5 to 76.55 VillVillage [drawing: arch bridge] to Rright 20 p 7 Vill R.

35 p 7 Xcross [drawing: arch bridge] of a Rivr running R. 5 to 8 Vill R & 16th League. 12 p 8 Vill 1 mile R. a better country. 24 p 8 Vill R. 2 p 9 Valley X [drawing: arch bridge], river runs to R a Village.
League 17. ascend. heath. 10h a Vill. 5 p 10 X [drawing: arch bridge] to R. 30 p 10 League 10. Stream on R runs back to the Minho in a glen. Minho strikes off. 5 p 11 Vill. Glen, descent.
chestnuts, mountains rise finely
